Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Keyphrase Extraction in Document Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Keyphrases for a document concisely describe the document using a small set of phrases (i.e., sequences of contiguous words in a document). For example, the keyphrases "social networks" and "interest targeting" quickly provide us with a high-level topic description (i.e., a summary) of a document focused on targeting interest for recommending services such as products and news to users, in the context of social networks. Given today's very large collections of documents, these keyphrases are extremely important not only for summarizing a document, but also for the search and retrieval of relevant information. However, keyphrases are not always available directly. Instead, they need to be gleaned from the many details in documents. This project addresses the problem of automatic keyphrase extraction from research papers, which are enablers of the sharing and dissemination of scientific discoveries. The goal of the project is to explore accurate approaches that automatically discover and extract keyphrases in documents, using document networks, which will help users handle and digest more information in less time during these "big data" times. Educationally, this research will involve training of both graduate and undergraduate students in the active area of research of keyphrase extraction, which has high impact in many real-world applications such as online advertising, document categorization, recommendation, and summarization, Web search and discovery, and topic tracking in newswire.

Although much research to date has been done on automatic keyphrase extraction, no previous approaches have captured the impact of documents on one another via the citation relation that connects documents in a network. This project will investigate models that take into consideration the linkage between citing and cited documents in a document network and will explore various qualitative and quantitative aspects of the question: "What are the key phrases or concepts in a document?" Scalable iterative algorithms will be designed and developed that capture different aspects of documents (e.g., topics or concepts), as well as the impact of one document on another (e.g., influence or topic evolution) in a document network. The results of this research will have a direct pipeline to the CiteSeerX digital library (http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu). The software, tools, and benchmark datasets developed during the course of this project will be broadly disseminated via the project website (http://www.cse.unt.edu/~ccaragea/keyphrases.html). All findings will be shared to the research community through publications in academic journals and presented in Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Natural Language Processing conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Keyphrase extraction from scholarly documents improves indexing and retrieval of the documents in digital libraries. We aim to develop a method that is computationally feasible for the scale of CiteSeerX and improves accuracies over current methods. Knowledge graph (KG) construction from the scholarly documents aims to set the foundation for a novel sematic representation of the documents that will enable more advanced search and retrieval capabilities to digital libraries. We developed novel approaches for keyphrase extraction and knowledge base construction from scholarly documents.

Keyphrase extraction approaches largely rely on statistical features which limits their scalability to large data sets such as the ones in digital libraries. We exploit dependencies in the input text and their labels to predict keyphrases. We also use deep learning models for scalability. For KG construction, we develop an unsupervised knowledge acquisition model that does not rely on manually labeled data sources.

Our keyphrase extraction approach incorporates the semantic dependencies of the input and the labels by formulating the task as a sequence labeling problem. We applied a neural-based model with pre-trained word embeddings to better capture the semantics of the documents. The model outperformes existing methods on the F1 score as well as precision.

For cold-start knowledge graph construction, we adopted an iterative learning approach that relies on a rule-based bootstrapping phase to extract entities and their relationships and attributes. The application of the method to a set of 10k Computer Science papers generated a domain-specific knowledge graph with over 17k entities.

Our keyphrase extraction model showed promising results for both the sequence-labeling formulation of the problem as well as the neural-based model for training the classifier. This finding opens several research directions that include, but are not limited to, the exploration of other vector representations of texts in scholarly contexts and sequence labeling for keyphrase extraction.
